abstract.text: Animates changes to one or more views using the specified SwiftUI animation.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The animation to use for the changes.
A closure that contains the changes to animate.
A closure to execute after the animation completes.
Use this method to leverage SwiftUI animations from UIKit code, creating a more consistent animation experience if your app incorporates code from both frameworks.

Similar to animations in SwiftUI views, you can smoothly retarget the animations you perform using this method, preserving the velocity of the animations. The following code shows a basic example of retargeting an in-progress animation to a different location:

code: // Begins an animation to move the view to a new location.
// Retargets the running animations to move the view to a different location.

inlineContent.text: You can also retarget animations continuously. The following code shows an example of retargeting animations during a pan gesture. As a person uses a pan gesture to drag a view across the screen, the pan gesture continuously fires change events. Each change event creates a new animation with the
type, and each new animation retargets the previous one. When the gesture ends, a final noninteractive
animation uses the velocity from the previous
animations to carry the animation forward with continuous velocity, creating a fluid animation experience.
using a SwiftUI animation behaves differently from other
animations, these animations run in-process and don’t have a backing
. However, presentation values from these animations still reflect in the presentation layer object (

abstract.text: The abstract superclass for animations in Core Animation.
Returns a copy of the presentation layer object that represents the state of the layer as it currently appears onscreen.
A convenience for a `spring` animation with a lower `duration` value, intended for driving interactive animations.

A persistent spring animation. When mixed with other `spring()` or `interactiveSpring()` animations on the same property, each animation will be replaced by their successor, preserving velocity from one animation to the next. Optionally blends the response values between springs over a time period.
Create a consistent UI animation experience across SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Specifies the timing and animation values for a single frame of a keyframe animation.
Animates changes to one or more views using a spring animation with the specified duration, bounce, initial velocity, delay, options, and completion handler.
Animates changes to one or more views using the specified SwiftUI animation.
Animate changes to one or more views using the specified duration.
Animate changes to one or more views using the specified duration and completion handler.
Animate changes to one or more views using the specified duration, delay, options, and completion handler.
Performs a view animation using a timing curve corresponding to the motion of a physical spring.
Creates an animation block object that can be used to set up keyframe-based animations for the current view.
The view’s Core Animation layer to use for rendering.
Repeats the specified animations a specific number of times, optionally running the animation forward and backward.
Performs a specified system-provided animation on one or more views, along with optional parallel animations that you define.
Disables a view transition animation.
Creates a transition animation between the specified views using the given parameters.
Creates a transition animation for the specified container view.
The way a view changes over time to create a smooth visual transition from one state to another.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
